params.text: 3D printing process

The whole process of developing a rapid prototype can be divided into 9 steps:

  1. Measurement
  2. Computer Aided Design
  3. Conversion to STL format
  4. Slicing or conversion of STL File into commands for 3D printer
  5. 3D printer setup
  6. Build
  7. Removal from the printer
  8. Post-Process
  9. Application of the prototype

In this course we will focus on the first four steps.

This is in no way a complete overview, as the possibilities for both creativity and mistakes are almost limitless with 3D printing, but we will try to cover important parts and pitfalls to get you started.

 

To pass the course you must answer every question and click "Submit report" on the last page.
Applicability of a 3D print

While 3D printing is extremely useful and fast, it’s not magic and for some models it makes more sense to find them elsewhere, as it can be cheaper, more durable and/or faster.

Examples include:

  • Standardized parts, such as screws or bolts.
  • Completely flat strips or planes of material, which can be cut out of plywood or carton.
  • Big simple filled out shapes, such as a 100% infill 40x40x40 cube weighing about a kilogram of wasted filament.

params.question: 3D printing is magical in its capabilities and has no limitations.

params.text: Measurements
To make a 3D printed model that fits your design one of the reliable and the most useful tools for any engineer is the calipers. It is a simple tool with accuracy up to a 0.05 of a mm.

1. To measure the outside of the part you need to clamp it tightly in the calipers, minding that it should remain parallel to the scale.
  2. To find the parts length in millimeters you should look where the zero of the smaller sliding scale falls on the bigger stationary one. The “rough” length is the notch on the bigger scale to the left. In case of the picture it is 2.9 cm.
  3. To measure finer, you must find the section, where the notches on the smaller scale align perfectly with the notch on the bigger. The number on the smaller scale, in our case 0.4 mm, is then added to the “rough” measure: 29 mm + 0.4 mm = 29.4 mm
  4. To measure the inside of the part you can use the back part of the calipers as shown on the picture. Then go through steps 2 and 3.
Making sure that your part fits is a matter of trial, error and experience, especially with FFF 3D printing. Further are some pointers to make it easier to start.
Tolerances

If you have assemblies, sockets or movable parts, make sure you have enough space to allow for the parts to fit. Several trial runs may be necessary in the case of mechanical parts, but, in most processes, a minimum difference in size of 0.25 mm is necessary.

params.alt: The size of the original model for comparison with the measured.
params.title: The size of the original model for comparison with the measured.

params.text: Keep in mind that 3D-printer does not produce an object identical to your 3D model. Due to behavior of melted plastic the dimensions of the resulting detail can be slightly different from the desired. To prevent it keep in mind while modeling what dimensions are crucial and adjust them (increase or decrease) depending on the situation. For example, the hole for the standard M4 screw (which is 4 mm in diameter) should be approximately 4.2 mm, so the screw can smoothly fit, but not be loose. And once again, it is not a 100% guarantee. For each specific project different margins may apply.

params.text: Model Thickness

• A 3D model’s mesh is just a mathematical surface with no thickness: to make an object real, you should give a thickness value to the wall.
  • Ensure that the walls of your model are thick enough to be printed. The minimum thickness can vary depending on the printer and material. You can check if your feature will be printed in the slicing software. If a path for the print is generated, you should be on the safe side.
  • Generally, anything less than 1mm could be problematic.
Use your design software to inspect and adjust wall thickness. Most software, like SolidWorks or Autodesk Inventor, will have tools to measure and analyze model thickness.

answers.text: The slicing software generates a path for the print.
The model's mesh is complex.
The model looks visually appealing.
The printer makes no noise during the process.

params.text: Overhangs and Supports

Any part of your model that extends beyond a 45° angle may need support to be printed correctly.

  • Design with printing in mind, perhaps altering your model may reduce overhangs.
  • Alternatively, use slicing software to generate support structures that can be removed post-printing. Remember that supports might be hard and sometimes impossible to remove. Keep postprocessing in mind.
  • Think about the direction of the printing. Sometimes rotating the model can reduce number of supports needed and affect the sturdiness of the model.

params.text: Water-Tightness

The term "water-tight" in the context of 3D printing and CAD modeling describes a crucial characteristic of a 3D model, indicating that it has no holes, gaps or crossing planes, and all surfaces are correctly joined with no non-manifold edges.

Only a water-tight model can be printed correctly.

• Use the SolidWorks checking tool (or alternative in your modeling software) to find and fix any issues. Most professional 3D modeling software will have this capability.

Method 1: Use "Import Diagnostics"

  1. Open your SolidWorks model.
  2. Go to Tools → Import Diagnostics (only available if you import an STL, STEP or IGES file).
  3. If any faulty faces or gaps are found, SolidWorks will highlight them.
  4. Click Attempt to Heal All to fix minor issues.

Method 2: Check for Gaps Manually

  1. Use Zoom In to inspect small edges and surfaces.
  2. Turn on Wireframe View (View → Display → Wireframe) to see internal edges.
  3. Look for open edges (edges that should be connected but aren't).

Method 3: Use “Check Entity” Tool

  1. Go to Tools → Check.
  2. Select the body and click Check.
  3. Look for issues such as open surfaces or non-manifold geometry.

answers.text: The model has no holes, gaps, or crossing planes.
The model can float in water.
The model is lightweight and easy to print.
The model is designed for underwater applications.

params.text: File Size and Format
Ensure the file is in .stl format, which is commonly accepted by 3D printers.

• The resolution of your model determines how detailed the print can be. This is often related to the layer height and the printer's capabilities. A file with too much detail can be as problematic as the one with too little.
  • If your file is too large, consider reducing the resolution slightly or check if your modeling software has options to reduce file size upon export without losing critical detail.
  • 2D images and letters attached to a file won’t appear on a monochrome 3D print, but can still mess it up, unless they are transformed into a “bump map”

Export as STL from SolidWorks Correctly

  1. Click File → Save As.
  2. Choose STL (.stl) format.
  3. Click Options and set:
    • Resolution: Fine or Custom
    • Check “Binary” (smaller file size)
    • Output as “Solid/Manifold” if available
  4. Save the file and open it in Creality Slicer.

answers.text: .stl
.mp4
.jpeg
.docx

params.text: Slicing software

There is a lot of tutorials on 3D printing online and a lot of software for slicing. We recommend using and looking at the tutorial for Creality Slicer. We will come over some of the important or specific tools below. In our course the setting for layer height should be 0.2 mm. Printer model will be specified later.
Check the Model

Once the STL is loaded into Creality Slicer:

  1. Look for Warning Messages
    • If Creality Slicer detects holes or non-manifold geometry, it may suggest repairing them.
  2. Use the Preview Mode
    • Slice the model and check the layer view.
    • At this point you can check for features that are too thin for your printer, as they will not be visible on the pathing.
    • If you see gaps or missing layers, the model is not watertight.
  3. Use "Auto-Repair" in Creality Slicer
    • If errors are detected, the slicer may prompt you to repair them automatically.
    • If the auto-repair fails, go back to SolidWorks and fix the geometry manually.

metadata.title: Check the Model in Creality Slicer

params.text: Scaling

It’s better to check the scale of the model to be printed before exporting it. When you load it into other software, it may ask for the unit of measurement used. In some cases, STL files modeled in millimeters can appear in meters or even in inches when you load it into your 3D printer’s software. You’ll have to restore the correct ratio using your software’s Scale option to return them to their initial scale before manufacturing.
Orientation

• The orientation of your model on the print bed influences not only the appearance of the final print (due to layering) but also the probability of printing success.
  • Orient the model to minimize supports, which are hard or destructive to detach from the print and potential printing errors. You can preview and adjust orientation.
Infill

• The STL only contains the external walls of your objects: sometimes you will want them to be filled, and sometimes hollow for printing. Expressed as a percentage, the infill will be more or less dense depending on your needs. The higher the percentage, the denser the structure. Usually, these cells are shaped as hexagons or squares, but many other options may be available (MakerBot even has an infill setting using cat silhouettes).
  • Note that you won’t gain much by completely filling your piece: 20%, depending on the chosen pattern, is already quite rigid.

answers.text: The higher the percentage, the denser the structure.
It doesn't affect the structure, only the color.
A higher percentage results in a lighter structure.
Lower percentages result in a denser structure.

params.text: Postscript

Remember, that in HSHL students take are obliged to:

  • Take responsibility for own safety and health
  • Take responsibility for the safety and health of those higher education institution members who are affected by own actions

We highly recommend you familiarize yourself with any electrical or potentially harmful appliance by either looking at the manual or seeking instructions from someone more experienced with the equipment. This will help you avoid needless headaches and / or getting hurt.

Thank you for sticking with us through the safety section and making sure the labs stay safe and welcoming!
